In accordance with legal tradition, the Croatian Parliament is traditionally titled the Sabor.	U skladu s pravnom tradicijom, hrvatski parlament tradicionalno nosi naziv Sabor.	0.504167
The oldest preserved records of Sabor sessions date back to 1273, although the beginnings of the Sabor are much earlier.	Prvi sačuvani zapisnik saborskoga zasjedanja potječe iz 1273, premda se neki oblici sabora spominju mnogo prije.	0.470471
Alongside the Icelandic Althing, formed in 930, and the Parliament of Sicily, established in 1130, the Sabor is therefore one of the oldest Diets in Europe.	Tako je Hrvatski sabor, uz islandski Althing (930) i Sicilijanski sabor (1130), jedan od najstarijih u Europi.	0.183158
		0.3
In accordance with legal tradition, the Croatian Parliament is traditionally titled the Sabor.	U skladu s pravnom tradicijom, hrvatski parlament tradicionalno nosi naziv Sabor.	0.504167
The oldest preserved records of sessions of the Sabor date back to 1273.	Najstariji sačuvani zapisnik saborskoga zasjedanja potječe iz 1273.	0.623497
Until the 16th century, the Slavonian and Croatian Sabors sat separately, but from 1681 they were united in the Sabor of the Kingdom of Croatia, Dalmatia and Slavonia (Congregatio Regnorum Croatiae, Dalmatiae et Slavoniae).	Do 16. st. zasjedaju odvojeno Slavonski i Hrvatski sabor, a od 1681. zasjeda Sabor Kraljevstava Hrvatske, Dalmacije i Slavonije (Congregatio Regnorum Croatiae, Dalmatiae et Slavoniae).	1.05179
Until 1848, representatives were elected exclusively from the ranks of church dignitaries and the nobility, before the period when ordinary citizens were included.	Do 1848. zastupnici su se birali isključivo iz redova crkvenih velikodostojnika i plemstva, a otad nastupa građansko razdoblje.	0.223009
Until 1847, the official language was Latin, and from then on, Croatian.	Službeni jezik do 1847. bio je latinski, otad je hrvatski. ~~~ Za II.	-0.0103448
During the Second World War, the tradition of the Sabor was taken over by the ZAVNOH (National Anti-Fascist Council of the People’s Liberation of Croatia), which declared the National Sabor of Croatia in 1945.	svjetskog rata tradiciju sabora preuzeo je ZAVNOH, koji se 1945. proglasio Narodnim saborom Hrvatske.	0.196629
A single-party Sabor was formed during the time of Yugoslavia, but real power was concentrated in the Communist League.	Za Jugoslavije se sastajao jednostranački sabor, no stvarna vlast bila je koncentrirana u Savezu komunista.	0.277895
The first multiparty Sabor was constituted on 30 May 1990, and this day is celebrated as the Day of Hrvatski Sabor (Croatian Parliament Day).	Prvi višestranački Sabor konstituiran je 30.	0.178571
Since then, seven Parliaments have been constituted.	V. 1990. i taj se dan obilježava kao Dan Hrvatskog sabora.	0.280851
	Otada je konstituirano sedam saziva Sabora.	-0.3
		0.3
The Croatian Parliament is the representative body of its citizens and is vested with legislative power.	Hrvatski sabor predstavničko je tijelo građana i nositelj zakonodavne vlasti.	0.219718
It has a minimum of 100, and a maximum of 160, members.	Ima najmanje 100, a najviše 160 zastupnika.	0.628846
Members of Parliament have no imperative mandate and enjoy immunity.	Zastupnici nemaju obvezujući mandat te imaju imunitet.	0.24
The Croatian Parliament has a Speaker and one or more Deputy Speakers.	Hrvatski sabor ima predsjednika i jednoga ili više potpredsjednika.	0.295
The Croatian Parliament decides on the adoption of or amendments to the Constitution, passes laws, adopts the State Budget, declares war or peace, adopts documents through which the policies of the Croatian Parliament are expressed, adopts strategies of national security and defence, carries out civil supervision of the armed forces and security services, decides on border changes, holds referenda, conducts elections, appointments and dismissals, supervises the work of the Government and other holders of public authority answerable to the Croatian Parliament, grants amnesty for criminal offences, and performs other work laid down in the Constitution.	Hrvatski sabor odlučuje o donošenju i promjeni Ustava; donosi zakone; donosi državni proračun; odlučuje o ratu i miru; donosi akte kojima izražava politiku Hrvatskoga sabora; donosi strategiju nacionalne sigurnosti i strategiju obrane; ostvaruje građanski nadzor nad oružanim snagama i službama sigurnosti; odlučuje o promjeni granica; raspisuje referendum; obavlja izbore, imenovanja i razrješenja; nadzire rad Vlade i drugih nositelja javnih dužnosti odgovornih Hrvatskomu saboru; daje amnestiju za kaznena djela; obavlja i druge poslove utvrđene Ustavom.	0.259639
The Parliament may establish investigative commissions for matters in the public interest.	Sabor može osnivati istražna povjerenstva za svako pitanje od javnoga interesa.	0.266667
The Croatian Parliament building on St. Mark’s Square in Zagreb, opposite the seat of the Government.	Zgrada Hrvatskog sabora na Trgu svetoga Marka u Zagrebu, nasuprot sjedišta Vlade.	0.229167
The Parliament in session, 2012	Sabor, zasjedanje 2012.	0.218182
Composition of the Croatian Parliament after 2011 elections	Sadašnji sastav Hrvatskog sabora	0.0870968
Rožanski and Hajdučki Kukovi Strict Reserve, part of the North Velebit National Park.	Strogi rezervat Rožanski i Hajdučki kukovi u sastavu je Nacionalnog parka Sjeverni Velebit.	0.704887
The Velebit massif, spanning 145 km, is the longest mountain in Croatia and the fourth highest, culminating at 1,757 m, after Dinara (1831 m), Kame&scaron;nica (1809 m) and Biokovo (1762 m).	Velebitski masiv najduža je hrvatska planina (145 km) i četvrta po visini (1757 m), iza Dinare (1831 m), Kame&scaron;nice (1809 m) i Biokova (1762 m).	0.917889
		0.3
Although the land area of Croatia is not large (56,594 km², 19th in size among the countries of the European Union), it has an extremely varied relief, as it adjoins several large European relief forms.	Iako površinom nije velika (s 56 594 km² 19. je po redu u Europskoj uniji), zbog smještaja na dodiru nekoliko velikih europskih cjelina Hrvatska je reljefno raznolika zemlja.	0.266667
There are three main types of relief in Croatia: lowland Pannonian, mountainous Dinaric and coastal Adriatic.	Razlikuju se tri glavne reljefne cjeline: nizinska ili panonska, planinska ili dinarska i primorska ili jadranska.	0.284211
The lowlands occupy the largest area, with 53% of the territory under 200 m, while 26% of the country is hilly, with peaks between 200 and 500 m, and 21% lies over 500 m above sea level.	Pretežito je nizinska zemlja, čak 53% teritorija niže je od 200 m, oko 26% čine brežuljkasti krajevi i pobrđa visine 200–500 m, dok je 21% više od 500 m nadmorske visine.	1.048
The lowest areas are in the northeast region, which forms part of the Pannonian Plain, where the alluvial plains of the Sava, Drava and Danube alternate with the cinder plains of Baranja and Srijem.	Najniži dijelovi nalaze se u sjeveroistočnom dijelu zemlje, koji je dio Panonske nizine, gdje se smjenjuju aluvijalne ravnice rijeka Save, Drave i Dunava s lesnim zaravnima Baranje i Srijema.	0.3
		0.3
Further west, isolated, wooded peaks rise up from the plains to a maximum of 1,000 m (Psunj, Papuk and Krndija).	Zapadnije se iz nizine izdižu osamljena, šumovita gorja s visinama nižim od 1.000 m (Psunj, Papuk, Krndija).	0.793617
Along the edge of the Pannonian Plain is the hilly peri-Pannonian area with a large proportion of highland, sometimes exceeding 1,000 m absolute height (Medvednica, Ivančica, Žumberačka Gora).	Rubni dio Panonske zavale prelazi u brežuljkast peripanonski prostor sa znatnijim udjelom gorja, koja ponegdje premašuju 1000 m apsolutne visine (Medvednica, Ivančica, Žumberačka gora).	0.778214
The transition to the mountainous region is formed by the hills and limestone plateaus of Pokuplje and Kordun.	Prijelaz prema planinskomu području čine pobrđa i zaravni vapnenačke građe u Pokuplju i Kordunu.	0.283146
The real mountain region includes Gorski Kotar and Lika, with part of the Dinaric highland, basically lying NW-SE, with the highest mountains along the edges (Risnjak, Mala and Velika Kapela, Plješivica, Velebit and Dinara).	Pravo planinsko područje obuhvaća Gorski kotar i Liku, a dio je Dinarskoga gorja, osnovnog smjera pružanja SZ–JI, s najvišim planinama po rubovima (Risnjak, Mala i Velika Kapela, Plješivica, Velebit, Dinara).	0.967794
In Gorski Kotar there is a sharp contrast between the highland area and the deeply hewn river valleys of the Čabranka, Kupa and Dobra.	U Gorskom kotaru oštar je kontrast planinskog dijela i duboko usječenih riječnih dolina Čabranke, Kupe i Dobre.	0.261
In inland Lika there are extensive karst fields (Plaščansko, Gacko, Ličko and Krbavsko).	U unutrašnjosti Like prostrana su krška polja (Plaščansko, Gacko, Ličko, Krbavsko).	1.0462
		0.3
The coastal region extends from the mountains.	Primorski dio nadovezuje se na planinski.	0.267568
In the north, it includes the Istrian peninsula, while south of Rijeka the coastal belt is narrow, bordered by high mountains (Velebit) on one side and islands on the other.	Na sjeveru obuhvaća poluotok Istru, a južno od Rijeke usko i visokim planinama (Velebit) omeđeno primorje s otocima.	0.335565
The southern stretch of coastline corresponds to the historically established region of Dalmatia.	Južni dio primorja istovjetan je povijesno utemeljenoj regiji Dalmacije.	0.209091
The main feature of this area is the dominant karst relief.	Glavna je značajka toga dijela dominacija krškoga reljefa.	0.276
It is characterised by lengthwise zonality and the division into islands, the coastal belt and the hilly area of Zagora in the hinterland.	Karakteristična je njezina uzdužna zonalnost i podjela na otoke, priobalni pojas i brdovitu Zagoru u zaleđu.	0.238144
The coastal zone is proportionally narrow, bordered inland by steep mountain slopes.	Priobalna zona razmjerno je uska, prema unutrašnjosti omeđena strmim padinama planina.	0.27973
It is widest and lowest in the flysch zones of Ravni Kotari in the north, in the central Kaštel region, and in the River Neretva delta in the south.	Najšira je i najniža u flišnim zonama Ravnih kotara na sjeveru, oko Kaštela u srednjem dijelu i u delti rijeke Neretve u južnom dijelu.	0.289831
In the hinterland is Dalmatinska Zagora, a hilly region with several broad karst fields (Sinjsko and Imotsko).	U zaleđu je obale Dalmatinska zagora, brdovit kraj s nekoliko prostranih krških polja (Sinjsko, Imotsko).	0.671809
		0.3
About half the territory of Croatia is karst land, while part of the wider region is composed of the same material, Dinaric karst, named after the Croatian mountain, and continues into Slovenia in the northwest and Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro in the east and southeast.	Oko polovice hrvatskog teritorija krško je područje, a dio šireg područja istovrsne je građe, tzv. ~~~ dinarskoga krša, nazvana prema hrvatskoj planini, koje se nastavlja u Sloveniju na sjeverozapadu te u Bosnu i Hercegovinu i Crnu Goru na istoku i jugoistoku.	-0.00597345
Karst land is characterised by the predominantly underground circulation of water through porous carbonate rock (limestone, dolomite).	Za krš je karakteristična prevladavajuća podzemna cirkulacija vode u topljivim karbonatnim stijenama (vapnencima, dolomitima).	0.294872
As the water dissolves calcium carbonate, it creates characteristic surface formations (sink-holes, clefts, valleys, fields) and underground formations (chasms, caves, grottos).	Otapajući kalcijev karbonat, voda stvara karakteristične površinske (ponikve, škrape, doline, polja) i podzemne oblike (ponori, jame, špilje).	0.240909
About 50 caves deeper than 250 metres have been discovered. ~~~ Lukina Jama in the Hajdučki Kukovi region, in the Northern Velebit National Park, is among the 20 deepest caves in the world (explored to a depth of 1,421 m).	Poznato je pedesetak jama dubljih od 250 m. Lukina jama u predjelu Hajdučki kukovi u nacionalnom parku Sjeverni Velebit među 20 je najdubljih jama na svijetu (istražena do dubine od 1421 m).	0.214773
		0.3
Rivers arise from powerful sources, and may flow over or underground before emerging again at ground level in lower lying areas.	Rijeke izviru iz snažnih izvora, a uz površinski tok mogu imati i podzemni (ponornice), pa se na nižim razinama ponovno pojavljuju na površini.	0.253211
Submarine sweet water springs known as vrulje are common.	Česti su i podmorski izvori slatke vode, tzv. ~~~ vrulje.	-0.00306122
The karst land may be forested or completely bare.	Krš može biti pošumljen ili posve gol.	0.241667
Within Europe, Croatia is considered to be one of the classic karst countries.	Hrvatska se drži jednom od klasičnih zemalja krša u europskim okvirima.	0.290769
Almost all formations have developed, so some Croatian names for particular karst shapes have been adopted in international scientific terminology.	Razvijeni su gotovo svi oblici, pa su hrvatski nazivi za pojedine krške oblike prihvaćeni u međunarodnoj znanstvenoj terminologiji.	0.272034
The karst region includes the largest reserves of underground drinking water, which require special protection from the dangers of pollution.	U krškom području najveće su zalihe podzemne pitke vode, koje zbog opasnosti od zagađenja zahtijevaju posebnu zaštitu.	0.258333
Since the level of preservation is high, the Croatian karst region is of exceptional natural value in European terms.	S obzirom na to da je visok stupanj očuvanosti, područje hrvatskoga krša iznimna je prirodna vrijednost u europskim razmjerima.	0.261
The Slavonian plains, a lowland Pannonian landscape in the northwest of the country	Slavonska ravnica, nizinski panonski krajolik u sjeveroistočnom dijelu zemlje.	0.3
Plešivica Heights, hills south of Zagreb, which belong to the hilly peri-Pannonian border	Prigorje Plešivice, gorja južno od Zagreba, dio je brežuljkastoga peripanonskog ruba.	0.3
Gorski Kotar, part of the mountainous area in the hinterland behind Rijeka	Gorski kotar, dio planinskog područja u zaleđu Rijeke.	0.549333
Mljet National Park on the southern Adriatic coast	Nacionalni park Mljet na južnom dijelu jadranske obale.	0.592424
Dinara, a mountainous karst formation, whose highest peak is also called Dinara and is the highest in the country (1,831 m), on the border with Bosnia and Herzegovina	Dinara, planinski krški masiv s istoimenim vrhom, najvišim u zemlji (1831 m), na granici prema Bosni i Hercegovini.	0.499948
The River Neretva delta in the southern part of the coastal region, between Split and Dubrovnik	Delta rijeke Neretve u južnom dijelu primorja, između Splita i Dubrovnika.	0.237313
Relief map (names in Croatian)	Reljefna karta	0.0214286
Bijele Stijene (White Rocks), an area in Gorski Kotar with well developed karst formations; along with neighbouring Samarske Stijene, it has been protected as a strict nature reserve since 1985	Bijele stijene, područje u Gorskom kotaru s razvijenim krškim oblicima; sa susjednim Samarskim stijenama od 1985. zaštićene kao strogi prirodni rezervat.	0.377668
Karst region	Područje krša	0.225
Samograd Cave near Perušić in Lika	Samogradska špilja kraj Perušića u Lici.	0.234375
Modro Jezero (Blue Lake) near Imotski, filling a deep sink-hole, and protected as a geomorphological natural monument.	Modro jezero kraj Imotskoga ispunja duboku ponikvu, a zaštićeno je kao geomorfološki spomenik prirode.	0.467742
Neighbouring Crveno Jezero (Red Lake) is one of the deepest in Europe.	Susjedno Crveno jezero jedno je od najdubljih u Europi.	0.525
Sink-hole on Biokovo, a coastal mountain which has been protected as a nature park since 1981	Ponikva na Biokovu, priobalnoj planini koja je od 1981. zaštićena kao park prirode.	0.494015
Croatia is administratively divided into 20 counties and the City of Zagreb, which has the status of a county.	Hrvatska je administrativno podijeljena na 20 županija i Grad Zagreb, koji ima status županije.	2.87176
Each county has particular competence for general education, health, land use, economic development, transport and its infrastructure, and the development of educational and cultural institutions.	Županija u svom samoupravnom djelokrugu obavlja poslove koje se među ostalim odnose na obrazovanje, zdravstvo, prostorno i urbanističko planiranje, gospodarski razvoj, promet i prometnu infrastrukturu te na razvoj obrazovnih, zdravstvenih, socijalnih i kulturnih ustanova.	0.178613
		0.3
The basic units of regional self-government are the counties (županija in Croatian).	Temeljna jedinica regionalne samouprave je županija.	0.140816
The present administrative territorial division of the country was introduced in 1997, when the 1992 division was changed.	Sadašnja upravno-teritorijalna podjela uvedena je 1997. godine, kada je promijenjena podjela iz 1992.	0.250549
Smaller administrative territorial units within counties are cities/towns in urban areas, and municipalities in other areas.	Manje administrativno-teritorijalne jedinice u sastavu županija su gradovi u urbanim područjima odnosno općine u ostalim područjima.	0.267273
According to the 2006 Act, Croatia has 127 towns/cities and 429 municipalities.	Zakonom iz 2006. godine Hrvatska ima 127 gradova i 429 općina.	0.716667
The county, as a unit of territorial division in Croatia, has a long history.	Županija kao jedinica teritorijalne podjele u Hrvatskoj ima dugačku tradiciju.	0.267692
Counties are mentioned as early as the 10th century, first in the southern part of the country, and later in the north.	Spominje se od 10. st., isprva u južnom dijelu zemlje, a potom i u sjevernom.	0.143077
They continued to exist up to the 20th century, in different numbers and with changing territorial ranges, means of organisation and powers. ~~~ After the demilitarisation of the Military Border in 1881, there were 8 counties in the Kingdom of Croatia and Slavonia: Modruš-Rijeka, Lika-Krbava, Zagreb, Varaždin, Bjelovar-Križevac, Požega, Virovitica and Srijem.	U različitu broju te s promjenljivim teritorijalnim opsegom, načinom ustroja i ovlastima, održale su se do 20. st. Nakon razvojačenja Vojne granice 1881. na području Kraljevine Hrvatske i Slavonije bilo je osam županija: modruško-riječka, ličko-krbavska, zagrebačka, varaždinska, bjelovarsko-križevačka, požeška, virovitička i srijemska.	-0.000479233

		0.3
The City of Zagreb	Grad Zagreb	1.16364
Number of inhabitants (2011): 790,017	Broj stanovnika (2011): 790 017	0.86
Surface area in km²: 641	Površina: 641 km²	8.48333
At the Cetin Sabor in 1527, the Croatian nobles elected Ferdinand I of the Habsburg dynasty, independently of Hungary, as their king, thus affirming Croatian statehood.	Na saboru u Cetingradu 1527. hrvatski su velikaši neovisno o Ugarskoj izabrali Ferdinanda I. Habsburškoga za hrvatskoga kralja, čime su potvrdili hrvatsku državnost.	0.291667
		0.3
After the death of the last member of the Trpimirović dynasty, King Stjepan II, there was a battle for the throne in Croatia, which ended with the election of the Hungarian king, Coloman from the Arpad dynasty, and the contracting of a personal union with Hungary, which lasted until 1918.	Nakon smrti posljednjeg Trpimirovića kralja Stjepana II. ~~~ u Hrvatskoj je izbio prijestolni rat, koji je završio 1102. izborom ugarskoga kralja Kolomana Arpadovića za hrvatskoga kralja te sklapanjem personalne unije s Ugarskom, koja je potrajala do 1918.	-0.0127803
Within Within the new state union, Croatia retained territorial integrity until the reign of Bela IV (1235–79), who founded Slavonia as a new unit of the Croatian-Hungarian Kingdom, in the area which was formerly the Pannonian Principality.	U novoj državnoj zajednici Hrvatska je ostala cjelovita sve do vladavine Bele IV.	-0.274648
Its seat was Zagreb. ~~~ At the same time, the Venetians conquered much of Dalmatia, while the regions by the central courses of the Vrbas and Sana rivers belonged to Bosnia.	(1235–70), koji je na prostoru nekadašnje panonske kneževine osnovao Slavoniju kao novu jedinicu Hrvatsko-Ugarskoga Kraljevstva sa središtem u Zagrebu.	-0.00539568
After the Arpad dynasty died out, a war of succession ensued.	Istodobno su Mlečani prisvojili velike dijelove Dalmacije, a područja uz srednji tok rijeke Vrbasa i Sane pripala su Bosni.	-0.0230769
The Venetians took the remaining Croatian towns in Dalmatia, while the Bosnian rulers took southern Croatia from the Cetina River to the Neretva River.	Nakon izumrća Arpadovića izbio je prijestolni rat, Mlečani su osvojili preostale hrvatske gradove u Dalmaciji, a bosanski vladari južnu Hrvatsku od rijeke Cetine do Neretve.	0.24186
		0.3
In 1309, Croatia came under the rule of Charles I Robert, from the Naples branch of the Anjou dynasty.	Godine 1309. ~~~ Hrvatskom je zavladao Karlo I. Robert iz napuljskoga ogranka francuske dinastije Anjou.	-0.00882353
His son, Louis I (Louis the Great) again united Croatia and Slavonia, seized back the territories occupied by Bosnia (1357) and the Venetians (the eastern shore of the Adriatic from Istria to the Bay of Kotor, in 1358), and enabled economic development and integration processes to take place from the Drava River to the Adriatic Sea.	Njegov sin Ludovik I. Veliki ponovno je sjedinio Hrvatsku i Slavoniju, povratio od Bosne zaposjednute teritorije (1357) te od Mlečana istočnu obalu Jadrana od Istre do Boke kotorske (1358), pospješio gospodarski razvitak i integracijske procese između Drave i Jadrana.	0.317553
		0.3
During the reign of Louis’ heir, in the late 14th and early 15th centuries, a dynastic war developed, of which the Venetian Republic and Bosnia took advantage, again extending their territories into Croatian lands.	Za Ludovikovih nasljednika krajem 14. i početkom 15. st. došlo je do dinastičkoga rata, koji su ponovno iskoristile Mletačka Republika i Bosna za teritorijalno proširenje na hrvatske prostore.	0.277193
It was during this period that Dubrovnik began to arise in the far south of Croatia, built on the foundations of strong maritime, trade and crafts traditions, developing a rich culture, diplomacy, pharmacies and social institutions, and introducing mains water and a sewer system, among other things.	U tom je razdoblju na krajnjem jugu hrvatskog prostora započeo uspon Dubrovnika, koji je na podlozi jakoga pomorstva, trgovine i obrta razvio bogatu kulturu, diplomaciju, ljekarništvo, socijalne ustanove, vodovod, kanalizaciju i dr.	0.225
		0.3
In the mid 15th century, the Ottomans began to press forward into Croatian lands, particularly after Bosnia fell under their rule in 1463.	Polovicom 15. st. započeli su prodori Osmanlija na hrvatski prostor, učestali nakon pada Bosne pod njihovu vlast (1463).	0.268868
Their advance was halted by King Matthias Corvinus (ruled from 1458 to 1490), by the construction of a strong fortification system on the eastern borders of Croatia and Slavonia.	Njihov prodor usporio je kralj Matija Korvin (vladao 1458–90) izgradnjom snažnoga obrambenog sustava na istočnim granicama Hrvatske i Slavonije.	0.254198
However, defences were weakened after a victory by the Ottomans at the Battle of Krbava Field in 1493, in which the Croatian nobility was decimated.	Obranu je, međutim, oslabio poraz od Osmanlija u bitki na Krbavskom polju 1493. u kojoj je desetkovano hrvatsko plemstvo.	0.242857
		0.3
‘The Bulwark of Christianity’.	»Predziđe kršćanstva«.	0.244444
Antemurale christianitatis was the Latin expression used in diplomatic correspondence to describe Croatia (a letter from Pope Leo X sent in 1519 to the Croatian ban Petar Berislavić).	Antemurale christianitatis latinska je sintagma kojom se nazivala Hrvatska u diplomatskoj korespondenciji (pismo pape Lava X. upućeno 1519. hrvatskomu banu Petru Berislaviću).	0.558959
Simultaneously, the phrase ‘remnants of the remnants’ (reliquiae reliquiarum) was also used, an abbreviation for the ‘remnants of the remnants of the once great and glorious Kingdom of Croatia’ (reliquiae reliquiarum olim magni et inclyti regni Croatiae).	Istodobno se koristio izraz ostatci ostataka (latinski reliquiae reliquiarum), nastao skraćivanjem izraza ostatci ostataka nekoć velikoga i slavnoga Kraljevstva hrvatskoga (latinski reliquiae reliquiarum olim magni et inclyti regni Croatiae).	0.984793
Following the death of the last Croatian-Hungarian king, Louis II Jagiellon in the Battle of Mohács, the Croatian nobles elected Ferdinand I of the Habsburg dynasty as ruler in 1527.		-0.3
He opposed the pretender John Zápolya and fought against the Ottomans.	Nakon pogibije posljednjega hrvatsko-ugarskoga kralja Ludovika II.	0.295082
In order to strengthen the defences of Zagreb, the first joint Sabor (Parliament) of the Croatian and Slavonian nobility was held in 1558, at which the Croatian lands were united politically.	Jagelovića na Mohačkom polju, hrvatski su velikaši 1527. za vladara izabrali Ferdinanda I. Habsburgovca, koji se istodobno sukobljavao s protukraljem Ivanom Zapoljom i borio protiv Osmanlija.	0.285185
The Ottoman occupation of Croatian lands was halted in 1593 by the Battle of Sisak, and the Habsburgs established the Military Border for defence purposes in the border areas.	Radi jačanja obrane u Zagrebu je 1558. održan prvi zajednički sabor hrvatskog i slavonskog plemstva, na kojem je došlo do političkog ujedinjenja hrvatskih zemalja.	0.29589
The Military Border was not reunited with Croatia until 1881.	Osmanska osvajanja hrvatskih zemalja zaustavljena su 1593. bitkom kraj Siska, a radi obrane Habsburgovci su na graničnim prostorima osnovali Vojnu granicu (krajinu), koja je s Hrvatskom ponovno sjedinjena tek 1881.	-0.185763
		0.3
The dissatisfaction of the Croatian nobility with the commandeering of Croatian land, the desultoriness of the Habsburgs in terms of mounting a defence against the Ottomans, and their interference in the authority of the Croatian ban and the Sabor resulted in a failed anti-Habsburg plot in 1671, led by the ban Petar Zrinski and Fran Krsto Frankapan.	Nezadovoljstvo hrvatskih velikaša zbog komadanja hrvatskih zemalja, neaktivnosti Habsburgovaca u obrani od Osmanlija te njihovo upletanje u ovlasti hrvatskog bana i Sabora rezultiralo je 1671. neuspjelom protuhabsburškom urotom pod vodstvom bana Petra Zrinskog i Frana Krste Frankapana.	0.249012
The Habsburgs used the opportunity of crushing the plot to introduce absolute power over Croatia and Hungary.	Slom urote iskorišten je za uvođenje apsolutne vlasti Habsburgovaca nad Hrvatskom i Ugarskom.	0.264286
Croatia in the mid 14th century	Hrvatska sredinom 14. st.	0.247826
The Cetin Sabor.	Cetingradski sabor.	0.22
At the Cetin Sabor in 1527, the Croatian nobles elected Ferdinand I of the Habsburg dynasty as their king, independently of Hungary, thus affirming Croatian statehood.	Na saboru u Cetingradu 1527. hrvatski su velikaši neovisno o Ugarskoj izabrali Ferdinanda I. Habsburškoga za hrvatskoga kralja, čime su potvrdili hrvatsku državnost.	0.28951
Suleiman’s Bridge in Osijek.	Sulejmanov most u Osijeku.	0.25
The most famous Ottoman construction in Croatia.	Najpoznatija osmanska građevina na hrvatskom prostoru.	0.244186
It was built in 1566 according to the designs of Koca Mimar Sinan and was nicknamed ‘the eighth wonder of the world’.	Podignut je 1566. prema projektu graditelja Kodže Mimara Sinana. ~~~ Nazivan je »osmim svjetskim čudom«.	-0.0111702
It was burned down by the Croatian ban Nikola VII Zrinski in a conflict with the Ottomans.	U sukobu s Osmanlijama zapalio ga je hrvatski ban Nikola VII.	0.667308
The deaths of the Croatian nobles Petar Zrinski and Fran Krsto Frankapan, the bearers of the tradition of the Croatian state and the proponents of greater independence, took place in 1671 in Wiener Neustadt.	Zrinski. ~~~ Pogubljenje hrvatskih velikaša Petra Zrinskog i Frana Krste Frankapana 1671. u Bečkom Novom Mjestu, nositelja državne predaje i težnje za većom hrvatskom samostalnošću.	-0.010061
Croatia in the early 17th century	Hrvatska početkom 17. st.	0.2375
The Battle of Sisak.	Sisačka bitka.	0.24
The battle for the fortress of Sisak was fought between the Croatian-Austrian and Ottoman armies from 15 to 22 June 1593.	Bitka između hrvatsko-austrijske i osmanske vojske za sisačku utvrdu 15–22. ~~~ VI.	-0.0513158
The victory at Sisak brought a permanent halt to the advances of the Ottomans to the west and their occupation of Croatian lands, and created military equilibrium on the border with the Ottoman Empire.	1593. ~~~ Pobjedom kraj Siska trajno je zaustavljen prodor Osmanlija prema zapadu i njihovo osvajanje hrvatskih zemalja te je uspostavljena vojna ravnoteža na granici s Osmanskim Carstvom.	-0.00552147
The amphitheatre in Pula, known as the Arena, built in the first century, the sixth largest in the Roman Empire, could host 25,000 spectators.	Amfiteatar u Puli, znamenita Arena, podignut u 1. st., veličinom šesti u cijelom Rimskom Carstvu, mogao je primiti 25 000 gledatelja.	0.437772
Today, it is used for large cultural and sporting events.	Danas se u njemu održavaju veliki kulturni i sportski spektakli.	0.25102
		0.3
Thanks to trade routes and communications, the ancient peoples of the Bronze and Iron Ages living in the land which is present-day Croatia were in touch with the artistic output of the Greek and Etruscans from as early as the 8th century BC, but it was only with the arrival of the Greek colonists in the 4th century BC that conditions were established for the wider spread of classical civilisation on the eastern Adriatic coast.	Zahvaljujući trgovačkim putovima i vezama starosjedilački narodi brončanoga i željeznoga doba na tlu današnje Hrvatske već su od 8. st. pr. ~~~ Kr. ~~~ imali dodira s umjetničkom proizvodnjom Grka i Etruraca, no tek se dolaskom grčkih kolonizatora u 4. st. pr. ~~~ Kr. ~~~ stvaraju uvjeti za uspostavu i jače širenje antičke civilizacije na istočnoj obali Jadrana.	-0.282273
Through the Greek colonies, such as Issa (Vis) and Pharos (Stari Grad, on the island of Hvar), Greek influence spread, as evidenced in the script, coinage, trade, parcelisation of land and building of city walls.	Posredovanjem grčkih kolonija, kao što su Issa (Vis) i Pharos (Stari Grad na Hvaru), širi se grčki utjecaj prepoznatljiv u pismu, kovanju novca, trgovini, parcelaciji zemljišta i gradnji zidina.	0.687791
		0.3
	Od 2. st. pr.	-0.3
From the 2nd century BC onwards, Rome gradually established power and created administrative regions – the provinces of Dalmatia and Pannonia.	Kr. ~~~ Rim postupno organizira svoju vlast te stvara više administrativnih područja – provincija (Dalmacija, Panonija).	0.0697115
Cultural and economic development with the characteristics of Roman civilisation (urbanism, architecture, sculpture, cults, coinage and trade) first arose on the Adriatic coast, then further in the deep hinterland.	Kulturni i gospodarski razvoj s odlikama rimske civilizacije (urbanizam, arhitektura, kiparstvo, kultovi, kovanje novca, trgovina) najprije zahvaća jadransku obalu, a potom i njezino duboko zaleđe.	0.28125
Many settlements took on the characteristics of Roman towns (Parentium/Poreč, Salona/Solin, Iader/Zadar, Narona/Vid, near Metković, Aenona/Nin, Varvaria/Bribir) and forum complexes were built with basilicas, curias, thermal spas, etc. ~~~ There were also grand public buildings, particularly theatres (Pola/Pula, Salona/Solin) and amphitheatres (Pola, Salona, Burnum/Ivoševci, near Kistanje).	Brojna naselja stječu odlike rimskoga grada (Parentium/Poreč, Salona/Solin, Iader/Zadar, Narona/Vid kraj Metkovića, Aenona/Nin, Varvaria/Bribir), oblikuju se forumski kompleksi s bazilikama, kurijama, termama i dr., ali i raskošne zgrade javne namjene, osobito teatri (Pola/Pula, Salona) i amfiteatri (Pola, Salona, Burnum/Ivoševci kraj Kistanja).	0.189165
		0.3
In the Pannonian area thermal spa towns sprang up (Aquae Iasae/Varaždinske Toplice) and important towns, of which only a little of the architecture has been preserved (Siscia/Sisak, Marsonia/Slavonski Brod, Mursa/Osijek, Cibalae/Vinkovci).	Na panonskom području nastaju kupališna naselja (Aquae Iasae/Varaždinske Toplice) te bitniji gradovi, od kojih je uglavnom sačuvana oskudna arhitektura (Siscia/Sisak, Marsonia/Slavonski Brod, Mursa/Osijek, Cibalae/Vinkovci).	1.25272
A special place among all these was held by Diocletian’s Palace in Split.	Posebno mjesto među spomenicima zauzima Dioklecijanova palača u Splitu.	0.290625
Special achievements of Roman and Hellenistic building were the country estates of Brijuni and also Polače on the island of Mljet, roads (Salona-Sirmium, Emona-Sirmium), bridges and aqueducts (Diocletian’s Aqueduct).	Kao postignuća rimsko-helenističkoga graditeljstva ističu se ladanjsko-gospodarske vile (Brijuni, Polače na Mljetu), ceste (Salona−Sirmium, Emona−Sirmium) te mostovi i akvedukti (Dioklecijanov vodovod).	0.434793
		0.3
After Constantine’s edict on tolerance issued in 313, early Christian art began to flourish in a natural symbiosis with classical culture.	Nakon Konstantinova edikta o toleranciji 313. započinje procvat ranokršćanske umjetnosti u prirodnoj simbiozi s antičkom kulturom.	0.2975
The most important monuments of early Christian sacred architecture are found in Salona, and there are particularly important early Christian graveyards north of the town (Marusinac, Manastirine, Kapljuč).	Najvažniji spomenici ranokršćanske sakralne arhitekture nalaze se u Saloni, a osobitu vrijednost imaju ranokršćanska groblja sjeverno od grada (Marusinac, Manastirine, Kapljuč).	0.679823
After the Byzantine Empire, the eastern heir of the Roman Empire, became the main political force in Italy and on the eastern Adriatic in the mid 6th century, a series of forts were built to defend and control the shipping route, of which the Byzantine castrum on Veli Brijun is a fine example.	Nakon što je Bizant kao istočni nasljednik Rimskoga Carstva sredinom 6. st. postao glavnom političkom silom u Italiji i na istočnom Jadranu, za obranu i kontrolu plovnoga puta podignut je niz utvrda, među kojima se ističe bizantski castrum na Velom Brijunu.	0.345982
The Euphrasian Basilica complex in Poreč is another magnificent architectural monument from that period.	Veličanstven je arhitektonski spomenik iz toga doba i kompleks Eufrazijeve bazilike u Poreču.	0.271765
		0.3
At the end of the 6th century, high classical civilisation began to wane in Croatia.	Krajem 6. st. na području Hrvatske počinje nagli pad visoke antičke civilizacije.	0.287324
The reason for this was the economic disintegration of the towns due to ever more frequent raids by “barbarian” tribes.	Razlog je tomu gospodarsko propadanje gradova zbog sve češćih prodora »barbarskih« plemena.	0.233721
Statue of the Emperor Augustus wearing armour (late 1st century BC), one of 16 larger-than-lifesize marble statues of emperors and empresses found on the site of ancient Narona (Vid, near Metković).	Kip cara Augusta u oklopu (kraj 1. st. pr. Kr. ~~~ ), jedan od 16 mramornih kipova careva i carica nadnaravne veličine pronađenih na prostoru antičke Narone (Vid kraj Metkovića).	0.751316

Ivo Pogorelić (1958) has become prominent due to his expressly personal style of interpretation of the pianist’s standard repertoire.	Pijanist Ivo Pogorelić istaknuo se izrazito osobnim stilom interpretacije standardnoga pijanističkoga repertoara.	0.721538

		0.3
The coexistence of two types of performance in Croatian ecclesiastical music was the outcome of medieval European culture: Gregorian chant (preserved in the late 11th century Neum Codex) developed in Dalmatia and Istria into Glagolitic chant, first in Old Slavonic, then in Croatian, which has been maintained to the present day through oral tradition.	Supostojanje dviju izvedbenih praksi u hrvatskoj crkvenoj glazbi jedinstvena je pojava u kulturi europskoga srednjovjekovlja: uz gregorijansko pjevanje (sačuvani su neumatski kodeksi s kraja 11. st.), u 9. st. u Dalmaciji i Istri razvilo se glagoljaško pjevanje, isprva na staroslavenskom, potom na hrvatskom jeziku, a usmenom se predajom održalo sve do danas.	0.287
In the centuries which followed, vocal musical forms dominated, composed by people who were either born on the coast or had connections to it.	U nadolazećim stoljećima dominantni su vokalni glazbeni oblici sa skladateljima koji su djelovanjem ili podrijetlom vezani uz obalni dio zemlje.	0.28
During the Renaissance, Julije Skjavetić of Šibenik was a prominent composer, the author of a collection of madrigals and motets.	U renesansi se ističe Julije Skjavetić iz Šibenika, autor zbirki madrigala i moteta.	0.582519
The early Baroque period was the golden age of Croatian music; Ivan Lukačić was composing in Split, the Italian Tomaso Cechinni on Hvar, and Vinko Jelić, from Rijeka, published a collection of motets in Strasbourg.	Rani barok zlatno je razdoblje hrvatske glazbe; u Splitu djeluje Ivan Lukačić, na Hvaru Talijan Tomaso Cechinni, a Riječanin Vinko Jelić u Strasbourgu je tiskao zbirke moteta.	0.562987
In the late Baroque period, the church singer and opera composer Ivan Šibenčanin worked in England and Italy.	U kasnom baroku crkveni pjevač i operni skladatelj Ivan Šibenčanin djeluje u Engleskoj i Italiji.	0.647414
		0.3
The Classical period introduced the first prominent compositions for instruments.	Razdoblje klasicizma donosi prva istaknutija ostvarenja instrumentalne glazbe.	0.295833
In Dubrovnik, Luka Sorkočević composed eight three-movement symphonies in the pre-classical style, while his son, Antun Sorkočević, composed chamber music, and the poetess and artist Jelena Pucić-Sorkočević was numbered among prominent Croatian composers for her solo songs.	U Dubrovniku Luka Sorkočević sklada osam trostavačnih simfonija u pretklasičnom stilu, njegov sin, Antun Sorkočević, stvara komornu glazbu, a pjesnikinja i slikarica Jelena Pucić-Sorkočević sa svojim solo-popijevkama uvrstila se među prve hrvatske skladateljice.	0.823188
In Split, Julije Bajamonti, a doctor, polymath, organist and composer of the first Croatian oratorio, Prijenos Sv.	U Splitu djeluje Julije Bajamonti, liječnik, polihistor, orguljaš i skladatelj prvoga hrvatskog oratorija, Prijenos sv.	0.835227
Dujma (The Translation of St. Domnius) (1770), and the Requiem for Ruđer Bošković (1787), was active.	Dujma (1770), te Requiema za Ruđera Boškovića (1787).	0.726667
The organ builder Petar Nakić built about fifteen organs in Istria and Dalmatia and over 300 in Italy in the first half of the 18th century.	Graditelj orgulja Petar Nakić u prvoj je polovici 18. st. izgradio petnaestak orgulja u Istri i Dalmaciji te više od 300 u sjevernoj Italiji.	1.84974
The violin virtuoso Ivan Jarnović achieved worldwide fame and was the composer of a score of violin concertos; he was also the first person in the music world to introduce the romance as a slow movement.	Svjetsku je slavu stekao violinski virtuoz Ivan Jarnović, skladatelj dvadesetak violinskih koncerata, u koje je prvi u povijesti glazbe uveo romancu kao polagani stavak.	0.375405
		0.3
Musical events in the 19th century gravitated towards northern Croatia.	Težište glazbenih zbivanja u 19. st. premješta se u sjeverni dio Hrvatske.	0.280952
In 1827, the Musikverein was founded in Zagreb (today’s Hrvatski Glazbeni Zavod – HGK), the oldest music institution in the country, with a comprehensive musical library. ~~~ In 1876, the HGK opened the first public concert hall in Zagreb, and in 1829, founded a School of Music, which became the Conservatory in 1916, then the Academy of Music of 1922.	U Zagrebu je 1827. utemeljen Musikverein (danas Hrvatski glazbeni zavod, HGZ), najdugovječnija glazbena ustanova, s bogatom glazbenom knjižnicom, koja je 1876. otvorila prvu javnu koncertnu dvoranu u Zagrebu te 1829. glazbenu školu, koja će 1916. postati Konzervatorijem, a 1922.	0.0151111
The early Romantic Nocturne in F sharp major for piano, by Ferdo Livadić (1822), along with the nocturnes of the English composer, John Field, is considered one of the earliest works of its kind in European music.	Muzičkom akademijom. ~~~ Ranoromantični Nocturno u fis molu za glasovir Ferde Livadića iz 1822. drži se, uz nocturne engleskoga skladatelja Johna Fielda, najranijim djelom te vrste u europskoj glazbi.	-0.00255682
The enthusiasm of the Illyrian Movement, which reflected the spirit of romantic nationalism among the other Slavic people led Vatroslav Lisinski to compose the first national opera, Ljubav i zloba (Love and Malice) in 1846.	U zamahu ilirskoga pokreta te u duhu romantičkih nacionalnih pokreta drugih slavenskih naroda Vatroslav Lisinski 1846. sklada prvu nacionalnu operu Ljubav i zloba.	0.826399
Ivan Zajc was a major figure in the second half of the 19th century, with an opus which included the opera Nikola Šubić Zrinjski.		-0.3
He was also the Director of the Opera and Music School of the HGZ. ~~~ Franjo Ksaver Kuhač, the founder of Croatian musical historiography and ethnomusicology, collected folk songs.	Drugu polovicu 19. st. obilježio je Ivan Zajc, svojim skladateljskim opusom (opera Nikola Šubić Zrinjski), ali i kao ravnatelj Opere i glazbene škole HGZ-a, te Franjo Ksaver Kuhač, utemeljitelj hrvatske glazbene historiografije i etnomuzikologije, skupljač narodnih popijevki.	0.0757576
Among internationally renowned artists of the 19th century were the guitarist and composer Ivan Padovec, the violinist Franjo Krežma, and the singers Ilma Murska, Matilda Mallinger (who sang the part of Eva in Wagner’s opera Die Meistersinger in 1868 in Munich), Josip Kašman (the first Croat to sing for the Metropolitan, 1883–84), Blaženka Kernic and Milka Trnina.	Veliki međunarodno poznati umjetnici u 19. st. bili su gitarist i skladatelj Ivan Padovec, violinist Franjo Krežma, pjevači Ilma Murska, Matilda Mallinger (pjevala Evu na praizvedbi Wagnerove opere Majstori pjevači 1868. u Münchenu), Josip Kašman (prvi Hrvat u Metropolitanu, 1883–84), Blaženka Kernic i Milka Trnina.	1.30638
		0.3
In the early 20th century, the leading composer of modern music was Blagoje Bersa (Sunčana polja – Sunlit Fields, a symphonic poem).	Na početku 20. st. vodeći je skladatelj glazbene moderne Blagoje Bersa (simfonijska pjesma Sunčana polja).	0.615625
In the generation of composers who were named the ‘new national trend’, the most prominent were Josip Štolcer Slavenski (who was acclaimed in Donaueschingen in 1924), Krešimir Baranović (Licitarsko srce – The Gingerbread Heart 1924, the first modern Croatian ballet), Jakov Gotovac (Ero s onoga svijeta – Ero the Joker, the most popular Croatian opera) and Fran Lhotka (Đavo u selu – Devil in the Village, the most successful Croatian ballet).	U generaciji skladatelja tzv. ~~~ novonacionalnoga smjera najistaknutiji su Josip Štolcer Slavenski (afirmirao se u Donaueschingenu 1924), Krešimir Baranović (Licitarsko srce, 1924, prvi moderni hrvatski balet), Jakov Gotovac (Ero s onoga svijeta, najpopularnija hrvatska opera) i Fran Lhotka (Đavo u selu, najuspjeliji hrvatski balet).	0.608643
Boris Papandopulo produced a rich, stylistically diverse opus (Symphonietta for Strings), and represented a bridge to the later 20th century, when representatives of the avant-garde were spearheaded by the composer Milko Keleman (Transfiguration) and Ivo Malec (Cantate pour elle), with Stanko Horvat, Ruben Radica, Anđelko Klobučar, Dubravko Detoni, Igor Kuljerić joining them.	Boris Papandopulo, s bogatim i stilski raznolikim opusom (Sinfonietta za gudački orkestar) most je prema drugoj polovici 20. st. i nositeljima avangarde, koju predvode skladatelji Milko Kelemen (Transfiguracije) i Ivo Malec (Cantate pour elle), a pripadaju joj i Stanko Horvat, Ruben Radica, Anđelko Klobučar, Dubravko Detoni, Igor Kuljerić.	1.24748
The outstanding composers of the late 20th century are Marko Ruždjak, Frano Parač, Davorin Kempf and Ivo Josipović, who is present-day President of Republic.	Krajem 20. st. istaknuli su se skladatelji Marko Ruždjak, Frano Parać, Davorin Kempf i Ivo Josipović.	1.19882
		0.3
Great Croatian artists of the 20th century include the conductors Lovro Matačić, Milan Horvat, Berislav Klobučar and Vjekoslav Šutej, the bassoonist Rudolf Klepac, the horn player Radovan Vlatković, the pianist Ivo Pogorelić, and singers such as Zinka Kunc-Milanov, Dragica Martinis, Tomislav Neralić, Vladimir Ruždjak, Marijana Radev, Sena Jurinac, Ljiljana Molnar-Talajić, Ruža Pospiš-Baldani and Dunja Vejzović.	Među najvećim su hrvatskim umjetnicima 20. st. s međunarodnom karijerom dirigenti Lovro pl. ~~~ Matačić, Milan Horvat, Berislav Klobučar i Vjekoslav Šutej, fagotist Rudolf Klepač, hornist Radovan Vlatković, pijanist Ivo Pogorelić, pjevači Zinka Kunc-Milanov, Dragica Martinis, Tomislav Neralić, Vladimir Ruždjak, Marijana Radev, Sena Jurinac, Ljiljana Molnar-Talajić, Ruža Pospiš-Baldani i Dunja Vejzović.	1.13994
Tonko Ninić and Josip Klima are the best known pupils of the Zagreb violin school, which was founded in the 1930s by Vaclav Huml.	Zlatko Baloković, Tonko Ninić i Josip Klima najpoznatiji su učenici zagrebačke violinističke škole, koju je na Muzičkoj akademiji 1930-ih utemeljio Václav Huml.	0.841063
The Svetislav Stančić Zagreb piano school produced Melita Lorković, Darko Lukić, Ranko Filjak, Jurica Murai, Pavica Gvozdić and Vladimir Krpan, who founded the Croatian branch of the European Piano Teachers’ Association in 1987.	Iz zagrebačke pijanističke škole Svetislava Stančića potekli su Melita Lorković, Darko Lukić, Ranko Filjak, Jurica Murai, Pavica Gvozdić i Vladimir Krpan, koji je 1987. utemeljio hrvatski ogranak European Piano Teachers Association.	1.69596
Cello teaching reached world levels through the efforts of the Italian artist, Antonio Janigro, who also founded the Zagreb Soloists, and the composers Rudolf Matz and Valter Dešpalj.	Violončelističku pedagogiju na svjetsku su razinu postavili talijanski umjetnik Antonio Janigro, ujedno osnivač ansambla Zagrebački solisti (1953), skladatelj Rudolf Matz i Valter Dešpalj.	1.02342
In recent times, Monika Leskovar and the duo 2Cellos have assumed the mantle of fame.	U novije doba violončelističku slavu prenose Monika Leskovar i duo 2 cellos.	0.974661
Several international competitions are held in Zagreb: the Vaclav Huml prize for violinists, the Lovro Matačić prize for conductors, the Antonio Janigro prize for cellists and the Svetislav Stančić prize for pianists. The most highly regarded Croatian orchestras are the Zagreb Philharmonic Orchestra and the Croatian Radio and Television Symphony Orchestra, whose choir and Big Band are also esteemed, while among chamber ensembles with an international reputation, the Zagreb Quartet and Zagreb Soloists are prominent.	Najugledniji su hrvatski orkestri Zagrebačka filharmonija te ansambli Hrvatske radiotelevizije – Simfonijski orkestar, Zbor, Tamburaški orkestar i Big Band, a među komornim sastavima s međunarodnim ugledom ističu se Zagrebački kvartet i ansambl Zagrebački solisti.	0.360818
The most popular Croatian operettas are Mala Floramye (1925) and Splitski Akvarel (1928) by Ivo Tijardović, and the first Croatian rock opera, Gubec-beg (1975), by Ivica Krajač, Karlo Metikoš and Miljenko Prohaska, achieved great popularity. Jalta, Jalta (1971) by Alfi Kabilja and Milan Grgić is the best known product of the famous Zagreb School of Musicals.	Jalta, Jalta (1971) Alfija Kabilje i Milana Grgića najpoznatije je pak ostvarenje glasovite zagrebačke škole mjuzikla.	0.808412
In jazz, the Zagreb Jazz Quartet acquired fame in the 1960s, thanks to its founder, Boško Petrović and one of its members, the all-rounder Miljenko Prohaska (who composed Intima). The international Zagreb Jazz Fair had a great influence on the younger generation in the 1980s and 1990s, and the current jazz scene in Croatia continues to thrive. Morgen’ for his popularity in Germany, and the Zagreb chanson school of the early 1960s, made famous by Arsen Dedić, Hrvoje Hegedušić and Zvonko Špišić, to the victory of the pop group Riva at the Eurovision Song Contest in Lausanne in 1989 (Rock Me). The reputation of the international rock scene in the 1960s was enhanced by the singer and composer Karlo Metikoš, known abroad as Matt Collins (Ritam kiše), and the oldest rock groups which are still going today are Parni valjak and Prljavo kazalište. Ivan Lukačić (1587–1648) reached the heights of European early Baroque music with his collection of motets, Sacrae cantiones.	Ivan Lukačić (1587–1648) svojom je zbirkom moteta Sacrae cantiones dosegnuo vrhunce europske glazbe ranoga baroka.	1.02714

Ivo Pogorelić (1958) has become prominent due to his expressly personal style of interpretation of the pianist’s standard repertoire.	Ivo Pogorelić (1958), istaknuo se izrazito osobnim stilom interpretacije standardnoga pijanističkoga repertoara.	0.718269
